Pilot Overview
From August to October 2015, Energy Efﬁcient Technologies, LLC (EET) and Powertron Global (PTG), conducted a 
joint pilot project on three Regional Convenience Store Chain stores located in and around St. George, Utah.  A fourth store (Hurricane Store
#402)  that was initially included but later removed from the pilot for some unforeseen mechanical issues 
unrelated to the project involving one of the two main roof top units (RTUs). The primary purpose of this pilot 
project was to demonstrate the effectiveness of implementing PermaFrost NMR® technology into the HVAC and 
refrigeration systems located in each of the stores.  In addition to PermaFrost NMR®, a power factor technology 
called Circuit Master was also included in the pilot to ascertain its feasibility in future Regional Convenience Store Chain Adventure Store 
applications.
 
In order to provide conclusive results demonstrating the cost savings of the aforementioned energy conservation 
measures (ECMs), EET installed utility grade meters with logging capabilities to monitor only the HVAC and 
refrigeration power demand and energy consumption in each store. Baseline (pre) data was collected for two 
weeks before implementing the technologies on August 21st.  Results from power factor correction can be 
noticed immediately so their effect was calculated in the two days immediately preceding and following 
implementation of the Circuit Master devices at the electrical panel.  PermaFrost NMR® requires a minimum of 
350-400 hours of operation on the two rooftops units (RTUs) and multiple refrigeration units supporting each of 
the Regional Convenience Store Chain Adventure Stores before maximum savings are generated.  For this reason, the post data was 
collected after 30 September 2015 yielding the results summarized in subsequent sections. 
The HVAC and refrigeration equipment in this study are representative of a great majority of the portfolio of 
equipment operated by Regional Convenience Store Chain in their Adventure Stores. If thermal degradation is present in this pilot 
equipment, it is present in the entire inventory of Regional Convenience Store Chain cooling equipment. Energy savings calculations based 
on the improvement demonstrated in the pilot equipment (portfolio representation) can then be accurately 
extrapolated across the entire inventory of equipment.
As demonstrated in this pilot study, PermaFrost NMR® restores the capacity of cooling systems lost over time due 
to fouling of the heat exchange surfaces. Working in a complementary fashion, the Circuit Master technology is 
designed to block distortions in electrical power above and below the normal signal range and contains line ﬁlter 
capacitors to improve power factor. This allows induction power equipment such as HVAC and refrigeration 
compressors and fans to use less energy.

ECM Descriptions
PermaFrost NMR®
Even though the HVAC units at these locations appear to be in good
working condition, there is still an opportunity for energy savings.
All HVAC equipment experiences thermal degradation over time as internal surfaces
of heat exchangers lose their optimal thermal transfer characteristics. This
thermal inefficiency can increase electricity consumption by up to 30% within the
first five years of the equipment's life, resulting in reduced capacity, lower
efficiency, and higher operating costs.
PermaFrost NMR® addresses this degradation by creating a permanent thermal metal coating
on the internal surfaces of the coil system. This coating conditions the metal surfaces,
improving volumetric heat transfer properties and restoring capacity, all while also
protecting against corrosion. Working together, the kilowatt consumption of 
your HVAC system is reduced signiﬁcantly, lowering the cost to produce each ton of cooling. The installation of 
PermaFrost NMR® does not require any additional hardware, maintenance or downtime for installation, and will 
last for the life of the unit.
Circuit Master®
Circuit Master is a product that blocks distortions in electrical power above and 
below the normal signal range and contains line ﬁlter capacitors to improve 
power factor.  This allows induction power equipment such as HVAC, 
refrigeration, motors and pumps to use less energy.  Equipment lifespan is also 
increased and maintenance costs are reduced. This equipment is installed at 
the disconnect for each machine.

Monitoring Store Environments   
A key component of this pilot was to ensure the comfort of the Regional Convenience Store Chain Adventure Store customers and store 
personnel remained consistent while reducing the energy consumption required to do so.  As such, EET installed 
temperature monitors in each of the pilot stores. For completeness, internal temperatures were also collected on 
two other Regional Convenience Store Chain Adventure Stores in the same geographical area that were not included in this pilot.   
As illustrated in the chart below, the initial temperature analysis substantiated the team’s concerns that the 
Hurricane location had a signiﬁcantly higher temperature than all other stores due to HVAC maintenance issues 
unrelated to PermaFrost NMR® that were not corrected in a timely manner.  For this reason, the Hurricane 
Adventure Store was removed from the analysis.
The temperature analysis also showed that the Washington Adventure Store was operating at a much lower 
internal temperature than all the other stores. This presents an opportunity where the thermostat set points on the 
RTUs could be increased to save an additional 4% of the overall HVAC energy while maintaining the same 
comfort level as the other Regional Convenience Store Chain Adventure Stores.

Baseline & Post Energy Meter Analysis
The main purpose of the pilot was to show the energy savings when evaluating the Baseline (before) and Post 
(after) performance of the two ECMs, PermaFrost NMR and Circuit Masters. The energy data was collected 
simultaneously in each of the three stores on identical utility grade power meters set up to only measure the 
HVAC and refrigeration equipment every 15 minutes.  The data for each store was then grouped by similar 
exterior weather conditions in the respective baseline and post periods and then averaged together to get an 
accurate analysis of savings provided by the two ECMs.
